A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Free system of generators (basis) to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a free system of generators (basis) for an A-module M involves the idea of linear independence and generating a module. It requires that any linear combination of the basis elements that equals zero must have all zero coefficients. This definition focuses on the properties of linear combinations and the structure of the module with respect to addition and scalar multiplication.

The Associative Law, on the other hand, pertains to the associativity of a binary operation within a set. In the context of modules, associativity typically refers to the operation of addition or multiplication within the ring or field that defines the scalars for the module. However, the definition of a free system of generators does not directly involve the associativity of operations; it primarily concerns the uniqueness of expression of module elements in terms of the basis elements.

Therefore, while the associative property might be implicitly used in the broader algebraic structure (like in the ring or field operations), it is not directly necessary for the definition or understanding of a free system of generators. The definition of a free system of generators stands independently of the need to explicitly define the associative law in this context.
